Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2013 01:09PM redwolf8812 wrote: Before I started TDM1, I asked my oncologist what we would do if it didn't work at all.  She mentioned a few different things, but added that there was only @20% chance they'd work. So that proceeded to what I call a "cliff's notes to the talk", only because I refuse to ask or be told how many days, weeks, months, etc.  I also refuse to let my husband ask when I'm not around because I'm afraid I'll be able to figure out what the answer is by his words or actions.  The only comfort I got from my discussion with the onc was that she said liver failure (I have liver mets) causes you to slip into a coma before you pass away.  My biggest fear was always that I'd be in pain or discomfort and not be able to communicate it to anyone.  If it goes as she said, then it sounds as if I won't be too aware of my physical symptoms.  Penny Happy Fall Y'all

Posts.Content: May 14, 2015 02:39PM redwolf8812 wrote: I've been home since yesterday. I only spent two nights in the hospital. Missed my daughter's 18th birthday, although we did sing happy birthday with cupcakes at the hospital and then went out to dinner when I got home. I feel great, thanks be to God, except for some bloating and discomfort after eating, but I'll take it. Praise The Lord. The CT report says I have a small amount of ascites. I'm a big baby in the hospital. Someone usually spends the night with me, my husband, sister, best friend, etc. I'd rather my husband be home taking care of our family but he'd rather be with me because he says I don't remember everything to ask and everything that's told to me (he's right). It's nice to have someone there who can get up and get you cold water or the nurse, etc. The medical staff at the Hospital of UPenn are awesome. They always do their best to accommodate us. Thanks for all the prayers, thoughts, love, and hugs. You guys are amazing. We all are, and we should never stop praying for ourselves and each other, no matter how bleak things look. He calls us to do so. Penny

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2014 11:44AM - edited Oct 31, 2014 11:50AM by redwolf8812 I'm on it now.  It's a "push" and takes @5 minutes, depending upon the nurse.  You'll get zofran as a pre-med, also decadron if you want it.  I now decline the decadron and drink lots of fluids the day before, the day of, and the day after, and my side effects became much better.  Before, when I was taking the steroid and not drinking enough fluids, I got very nauseous, fatigued, and felt like I had the flu.  The decadron prevented me from sleeping and gave me such an awful taste in my mouth.  I'm much better now.  In fact, I just had an infusion 2 days ago, and I'm feeling great, thanks be to God!  You'll do fine - no worries. :-) Penny P.S.  I just wanted to add that some patients have to take the steroid because they get severe jaw pain - caused by the navelbine - which is prevented by the decadron steroid.  However, one time I felt the jaw pain coming on the day after my infusion, and the NP started me on a 3 day course of decadron and it immediately went away.  So, if I were you, I wouldn't take it unless you feel you need it, or your oncologist strongly recommends it.

Posts.Content: redwolf8812 wrote: Yesterday, we asked the doctor some hard questions and received honest answers. My next scan is on the 25th. If it shows tumor growth, I have other options, most are hard chemos, but there's only a 20-30% chance that they will work. The miracle drug Herceptin doesn't work in 30% of patients. I'm in that 30%. I most likely will try at least one more chemo but I don't look forward to the harsh side effects. The treatment (TDM1) I'm on now has been fairly easy so I pray that the scan shows it's working.  When I decide to stop all treatments, she told me that liver failure is pretty painless. I would just fall asleep, be in a coma for a couple of days, and then pass away.  Not the kind of answers I wanted, but it is what it is. "Help me. Posts.Content: Nov 10, 2014 12:43PM redwolf8812 wrote: Hi, Tracey. You're welcome to join us at the thread https://community.breastcancer.org/forum/8/topic/8.... It's specifically for those with liver mets. You'll find a lot of useful info and you can post questions on your mom's behalf. There are women who have been fighting liver mets for years. There's always ups and downs with mets. Some chemos work, some don't. Some scans show progression, some show "NED" (no evidence of disease). This is what I pray for your mom. Stable is also a good thing to shoot for. Besides chemo, there's also targeted treatments for cancer in the liver, like ablations, SIR-spheres, and SBRT. A good website for liver metsters is https://www.beatlivertumors.org. Hang in there. - Penny

Posts.Content: redwolf8812 wrote: Kelly hasn't been on here in a while and since I thought some may be wondering about her, she said I could post on her behalf. She's been fighting Stage 4 ILC her2+ for about 11 years now. Lately it's been getting worse. As most of you know, ILC likes odd places to settle. She's been through a lot of treatments and clinical trials but still keeps the faith. Here is a copy of her last message to me: "...Not sure exactly what's going on Bc bilirubin is still too high. I really need tx. Tonight could tell the omental mets are bigger, similar to ascities it's like walking around carrying extra weight and I cannot stand up straight. Unlike ascities which at least could be drained just need tx to debulk them. Scary that it's 10 days and I still look a little yellow. Been sitting with Shay (Kelly's son) at night. Trying to lay groundwork a little that I may not get much better. Pallative care from Holy Reedemer comes Tuesday...Nurse checking in, social work. Maybe even help with house stuff. My insurance has been giving us a hard time with my drugs. Chuck (Kelly's husband) is fighting trying to get hours at work. The demotion thing isn't really working out but like he said is this best time to switch even if he could find something. So he is busy with that . Last week he was 2 hours away. I have advocated for myself forever and I just don't have it in me to deal with insurance. So they can help with that stuff too. I'm pretty much done with last oncologist except for the procedure again (Kelly had a stent put in her bile duct) if I can have it done. I am so upset with my treatment there. In hindsight my CT scans show progression in OCT. Should of been off trial then. I asked about liver MRI in OCT. Was told to ignore it. Only time anyone talked to me was when I sent threatening emails. Doctor admits she may of 'under appreciated' aspects of my disease. She ignored my liver for three weeks until I sent email that said, I could be dead, no one is addressing this except research nurse who said think positive. I'm telling her how bad I feel and she is like so your breathing is better. No it's worse. Having issues on steps. So if I cannot put better in chart can I put the same. I'm like I guess you are going to put whatever you want down despite what I say. ITS WORSE. Then I swore I was in twilight zone. In dec, tell trial nurse the pills really aggravate my reflux. She says absolutely not. That isn't possible and it must be something else. Then in jan she asks if my reflux is worse weeks on pills and Herceptin . I saw no it's bad in general but you said pills don't do that, she is like I never said of course they can. Chuck is like no you said exact opposite and the there was the "bad batch" of taxol I got that caused the rash. If they didn't almost kill me it would be funny. But I'm where I am Bc I didn't listen enough to my inner voice. I trusted wrong people. But it's not in my hands. I grateful and thank God for each day. Mets to so many many places. Not a lot of mbcers are still waking up with these mets. God has blessed us. I have havelen and navelelbine left. I didn't tolerate perjeta well but besides yourself I know two others that did the p/h with navelbline. So plan is if I can get liver to normal and have tx. Try havelen and then have p/h/n left. I just don't think I have the strength right now to do perjeta. I stopped it Bc of side effects cancer was stable. Exactly the same. Share my story anywhere. I always say, If I had to go through and something I did or went through helps someone out, maybe gets them out of dark place or helps with tx or se . I'm all for it. Last year a lady in FB was told she had stomach nets. Nothing to do and should go home and die. I said , have you tried TPN. How about some other things. She was where I was in 2012 with gastroparesis and bowel obstruction. Etc....She found new doc, went on TPN and has pretty good quality of life now. 9 months later. I feel like whole experience I went through really helped someone else out. Love Kelly" ...but he said to me, “My grace is sufficient for you, for power is made perfect in weakness.” I will rather boast most gladly of my weaknesses, in order that the power of Christ may dwell with me. Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2014 12:30AM redwolf8812 wrote: Here's been my experience if it helps.  I was originally on navelbine 2 weeks on, 1 week off.  After the 1st treatment, my white blood cell count plummeted so much and took so long to creep back up that my 2nd dose was never administered for 3 weeks. After THAT infusion, my WBC's dropped, I developed a fever and landed in the hospital.  So the oncologist tried lowering the dose.  Still didn't work.  Landed in the hospital again - same thing.  Now, I get Navelbine every other week, with a Neulasta shot the day after each infusion.  I also learned to drink plenty of fluids the day before, and day of, an infusion, in addition to bland foods the day before and day of (turkey, bananas, toast, crackers, ramen noodles, etc).  These things seem to help, thanks be to God.  My WBC's have been behaving and I've been feeling much better.  Like Sue, I also get Perjeta and Herceptin, but those are administered every 3 weeks, so we've really gotta be on our toes knowing which week I get what LOL. Hope this helps.  Praying for your mom (and you). - Penny

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 05:42AM redwolf8812 wrote: I developed skin mets during neo-adjuvant chemo, at the end of taxol and herceptin.  I was scheduled to go on adriamycin and cytoxan (AC) and went ahead with it, which did the trick of killing the skin mets.  The rash was always there, but faded from bright red to tan by the end of the AC (@ 6 weeks).  3 weeks after finishing AC, I had a double mastectomy, no reconstruction.  The pathology of the breast and skin came back as a complete response - no cancer.  I then had radiation, with "boosts" to the skin.  I finished rads April 2011.  7 months later I was diagnosed stage 4 - creepy cancer took up residence in my liver.  I'm not telling you that to scare you, but you may want to ask for a scan.  I had no symptoms of the liver met - I just wanted assurance that it was truly eradicated when I was done treatments.   Also, they biopsied the skin mets to make sure it was the same receptors as the tumor (it was), and the liver also (it was).  I didn't try xeloda until it showed up in my liver - it didn't work for me, but that doesn't mean it won't work for you - it sounds like it may be doing the job for you. Hope this info is of some value to you.  Prayers....  Penny

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2012 07:32PM redwolf8812 wrote: The tumor in the left lobe of my liver, which was up to 11cm last year is now down to 2 pieces, one is 3x2cm and stable (thank You, Lord!); the other has doubled in size since my last scan 9 weeks ago! It's @2.4x2.3cm. The oncologist is waiting to hear back from the interventional radiologist to see if he still wants to ablate. If he does, assuming it's soon, I get a chemo break until after Christmas! Sweet Jesus! Then it's onto either halaven or gemzar with herceptin. They're "confident" that T-DM1 will be approved by February (gee, where have we heard THAT before?). I would prefer Gemzar, but Xeloda is also an antimetabolite (like Gemzar) and did absolutely nothing for me. (But then again, neither did herceptin). But I don't relish the side effects I've read about halaven. At this point, I don't know what to pray for, except guidance, because in the past, when I've fought for things, they've backfired. LOL - I still have the battle scars from the tykerb to prove it. I also seem to be allergic to carboplatin so who knows what kind of reaction I'll have to the next thing? Not the news I wanted, but it could've been worse, so again, I praise God for all His Blessings. I'm in His Hands. Thank you all for your support and guidance and hope that maybe someone has more input/advice for me. - Penny

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 09:25AM redwolf8812 wrote: I take an anti-depressant (remeron) at night that also acts as a sleep aid.  If I don't get enough sleep, it affects my moods in a negative way. Hope this helps - my depression/anxiety is worse in the morning, before I get out of bed.  Most people say I should be happy to be given another day and I am truly thankful to God for each day, but in order to get out of bed, I have to set my alarm for @ 1 hour before I actually have to be up.  When the alarm goes off, I take the little medicine cup on my nightstand, throw back the pills in it, take a sip of water, and go back to bed (I put the pills in the medicine cup the night before).  By the time I actually have to get up, it's a lot easier.  The pills are oxycodone for the neuropathy and joint pain, ativan for the anxiety, and a ritalin for fatigue.  Sometimes a compazine if I just had treatment.  I still have some rough mornings but this mostly helps.   Besides daily prayers, I also try to attend mass and/or go to adoration every day.  God is my rock. Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 09:17PM - edited Mar 15, 2014 09:20PM by redwolf8812 I was diagnosed Stage 3 in July 2010 with a huge tumor in my left breast, after going for a routine yearly mammogram.  Started taxol & herceptin August 2010.  By October 2010 the cancer had spread to the skin on the breast, making me Stage 3C.  I started adriamycin and cytoxan in November 2010 and had a double mastectomy and complete hysterectomy (I'm BRCA2+) in January 2011.  At the time of surgery, all the cancer was gone, even in 7 of the 9 lymph nodes they took out.  My medical team was thrilled and felt confident I was completely cured as I went on to finish my year of herceptin.  At the end of that year, in November 2011, I had a pet scan.  My oncologist and I kind of went back and forth on whether to have it or not.  In the end, I decided I wanted to make sure that an internal mammary node was definitely cancer-free.  Thank The Lord because a 9 cm tumor lit up in my liver!  I wasn't having any symptoms, either.  So as of November 2011, I've been stage 4.  I've had successes and failures with different treatments and trials - you can see them on my page.  Right now I'm on perjeta, herceptin, and navelbine (my 2nd cycle) and I feel as If I've had only a few good days since starting, but I still thank The Lord for guiding me, my family, and my medical team.  I'm blessed to be here another day. Prayers for all. Love, Penny P.S. Forgot to add - I'm 44, married, with kids currently aged 19 (boy), 16 (girl), and 10 (girl). They are a huge help!

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2015 12:33AM redwolf8812 wrote: Hi, sharronsp. So sorry to welcome you here and to know that you're having such a rough time, along with the stress that goes along with moving. It's important to get something in you that will stay down. Your body needs good nutrition to fight those liver mets. Have you tried ensure or something similar? How about yummy smoothies made with just fruit and crushed ice (the dairy from yogurt probably won't agree with you). At the very least, I'd try some gatorade to get some important electrolytes back into your system. What kind of nausea meds have you tried? Sometimes I have to take both zofran and compazine at the same time to successfully fight off the nausea. I pray the doctors give you better advice or at least set you up with a nutritionist. I know others will come along and give you some more advice here, also. Do you have any help? You're exhausted and it would help if there were someone to make you some dry toast or heat up some broth for you. If anyone offers help, don't be afraid to take it and be specific about your needs. Trust me, we've all learned that the hard way. Keep us posted on you. - Penny

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2015 08:34AM redwolf8812 wrote: Radiofrequency Ablations on the liver for breast cancer mets is not experimental, but not done a lot. Maybe that's why you're having a hard time with the insurance coverage, cbrogdon. They've been doing them for years on colon and prostate cancer mets, and, of course, primary liver cancer. So many oncologists are opposed/unwilling to think outside the box that most of the time, bc patients with liver mets aren't even aware of the option. My first oncologist sort of waved her hand at me when I brought it up, along with chemoembolization, SBRT, and surgery, and said something to the effect that I shouldn't worry myself about all that. The oncologist I see now is much more open-minded and respects the fact that I research this stuff on my own. Doesn't make me feel like I'm trying to undermine her expertise, doesn't get offended, etc. Prayers for all, Penny

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2014 09:12AM redwolf8812 wrote: Dear Leah: I remember reading about your ordeal. I'm glad you're back on a treatment that's working. I went through something similar. I came down with hepatitis-E, yes, E. Should've seen me. Yellow skin and eyes. Orange urine. Liver function numbers quite high. The doctors all said that with people traveling so much, they're seeing more and more of this type of hepatitis. They got me stable in the hospital and right before they discharged me, took more blood samples. Went I got home, I started taking a prescribed med to kill the hepatitis. I was freaking out because I was told no cancer treatment until the hepatitis cleared up. A couple of days after I got home, I got a call from the GI doc - the bloodwork they took right before I was discharged showed no more hepatitis. She was amazed. I call it a miracle from God. I was able to go right back on treatment. All in all, I was off treatment about a month. A real nail-biter. I'm so Blessed. :-) Penny

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2015 12:47AM redwolf8812 wrote: Hi, Allyme. Sorry about your diagnosis. NED is the acronym for "No Evidence of Disease". As stage 4, it's assumed that there are always cancer cells floating around in your bloodstream somewhere, but if you're declared NED, it means that there is nothing large enough to be detected on scans. Some never get to NED. Some have it for weeks, months, or even years. As stage 4, you'll always be on some kind of treatment, whether it's just chemo, chemo with anti-hormonal meds, just meds, perjeta and/or herceptin, or whatever cocktail the oncologist and you decide is best for you. You'll even be on something if you reach NED status. Your hair will come and go, probably several times through the years, depending upon what treatment you're on. You can ask to referred to an Interventional Radiologist (IR) to discuss targeted treatments on the liver, such as ablations, Sir-spheres, chemoembolization, Stereotactic Body Radiation Treatment (SBRT), or even surgery. Some patients have had better success with these treatments then with systemic (chemo, etc). Everyone is different, including your body's reaction to treatments. I say thank The Lord for the great scan showing no progression. Since you have no pain and no vomiting, I'd ask the oncologist if the mets have shrunk. Be your own advocate - learn your pathology (er/pr status, grade of cancer, etc). Learn about treatment options. Don't be afraid to get 2nd opinions. My first oncologist would not refer me to an IR. My current one has no problem working with one. Keeping you in prayer. Keep us posted. - Penny

Posts.Content: Dec 10, 2014 05:15PM redwolf8812 wrote: I met with the Interventional Radiologist today and we've decided to try a procedure using "SIR-Spheres". To keep it short, they basically send microscopic beads containing radiation directly into the tumors in my liver. I have to get it done twice, once for each lobe. It's outpatient. Tomorrow @9:30 I'll be doing a simulation. They'll do everything that's done in the real procedure except the beads won't have radiation in them. This is done to make sure that the beads don't have a way to escape and travel to another organ. Between prepping, the procedure, and recovery, I'll be there all day. The 1st actual procedure may not be until after the holidays but we'll see how everything goes. I will probably be very tired tomorrow night, but I'll post an update if I can. Thanks for all your prayers. :-) Penny

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2015 12:54PM redwolf8812 wrote: Hi, Ella. I understand your fears. We probably all still get scared from time to time. You'll find the fear subsiding as the years go by. There are so many women out there who have been living with liver mets for years and years, probably because there are so many treatment options. Besides chemo and hormonal therapy, there's Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA), Sir-spheres, Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT), Chemoembolization, and surgery. Some of these procedures can be done more than once. Just make sure you have an oncologist who is willing to consider those options. You'd have to consult with an Interventional Radiologist for all of them except the SBRT and surgery. SBRT is done by Radiation Oncologists and surgery is, of course, done by a surgeon who specializes in the liver. A great website to check out is: http://www.beatlivertumors.org Prayers, Penny

Posts.Content: Nov 4, 2014 10:11AM redwolf8812 wrote: Dear macska-ma:  I wish I could tell you not to worry, but I know that never works for me.  All I can say is that there are so many chemos and cocktails you haven't tried yet.  Your doctors haven't given up on you yet - they know there's tons of stuff to try.  Keep in mind that there are also targeted treatments for the liver, like ablations, SIR-spheres, and SBRT.  You may want to make an appointment with an interventional radiologist to discuss those options, even if your oncologist discourages it (many oncologists are not up on the latest success rates of these targeted treatments).  Procedures like that can keep you going for months, if not years.   Prayes for you and yours, Penny

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2014 07:53AM redwolf8812 wrote: Hi, all.  I was diagnosed with a 9cm tumor in my liver in November 2011, after having finished all my chemo for Stage 3C breast cancer.  So glad I had that pet scan - I had no symptoms - we just wanted to make sure we got it all.  Been on several chemos, 2 trials, had 2 ablations.  They've "waxed and waned" and now there's also a suspicious spot on a left rib.  I've just started a trial where I get palbociclib and herceptin - my first scan since starting is on the 6th.   How is everyone's weight and energy?  I'm fighting 20 pounds I've put on since diagnosis.  I try to bike and lift light weights but it's still sticking around (I know it's my poor eating habits).  I've gone up 2 or 3 sizes.  Yuck. Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2015 11:30PM redwolf8812 wrote: Ella - I had it done twice. Sometimes the IR (Interventional Radiologist) will use ultrasound to guide the stereotactic needle, but mine were done using CT scans. The liver area is numbed up and you're given twilight sedation. They wake you up periodically to breathe so they can locate/burn the area. Depending upon the size/number of mets determines the amount of time it takes, but I think @45 minutes is the average. Recovery is easy. They keep you in a room for about 4 hours before sending you home. The IR will probably scan you about a month afterwards to see how well it worked. I did not have a lot of pain at all. God bless you. All will be well. Keep us posted. :-) Penny

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2011 08:44PM redwolf8812 wrote: As of today the receptor status is unknown so no treatment plan yet. The "medical team" seems sure that it will be the same but nothing will surprise be at this point. From the beginning none of my reactions have been "normal". The taxol/herceptin was shrinking my breast tumor but I still developed skin mets before finishing. Then I went on to epirubicin and cytoxan. By the time I got to surgery I had a complete response. Since we were concerned about the effectiveness of herceptin I went on tykerb while on herceptin after surgery. I developed a vicious allergic reaction to tykerb - a disgusting, itchy rash on my entire body. Every doctor on my team was positive that I was cancer-free, due to the complete response at surgery. When I was all done herceptin and had a pet/ct I was the only one not surprised that mets appeared, even though I had no symptoms. I have remained positive and prayerful but cancer plays by no rules, especially with me.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 05:44PM redwolf8812 wrote: Hello.  Diagnosed stage IIIc July 2010. Large Tumor in left breast. Large left node. Internal mammary node and sub pectoral node. BRCA2. Started August 2010 taxol and herceptin every week 12 weeks. Developed skin mets on breast towards end of TH. Moved on to epirubicin and cytoxan every two weeks, which completely obliterated the tumor and skin mets. Surgery pathology - only residual remained in 2 nodes and in lymphovascular. All tumor in breast and skin was gone. Clear margins. Continued with herceptin until November 2011. Rads from February 2011 to April 2011. All docs impressed with pathology and convinced I was cured but now facing mets, so what gives? Liver mets 11/11. Xeloda & Tykerb 12/11. Severe allergic reaction to tykerb 12/11, Xeloda only, praying about T-DM1 trial.  Added herceptin January 2012. - Penny, from South Jersey

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2012 09:48AM redwolf8812 wrote: We're down in Disney World - our first time since my stage 4 diagnosis. I remember all the times when my husband and children couldn't keep up with me in the parks and I was the one who knew where every attraction was. Now I'm either in a wheelchair or hobbling along with my cane while my 14-year-old daughter guides us with a park map. I fell asleep on Spaceship Earth in Epcot. I'm a little too "off" to do any thrill rides, which used to be my passion. I'm heavier, hairless, and I still have scars all over my arms and legs from an allergic reaction. However, I KNOW how blessed we are to even do a vacation. I thank the Lord for these times with my family. :-)
Posts.Title: So you remember what normal feels like? apple nancyh

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2012 07:16AM - edited Apr 21, 2012 07:16AM by redwolf8812 Sorry, Ann!  Just went through this myself @ 1 month ago.  Went to an amazing woman and purchased two new wigs, one short (by Revlon), one long (by Envy).  Also had her "tune up" the one long one I bought two years ago.  The ends were tangled and fuzzy so she cut it into a cute short style.  I now have three to play with, and am having a lot more fun with it then I did when I was only stage 3.  They're adjustable, so I loosened them and found they're a lot more comfortable.  She also told me something I would never think of - my wigs are synthetic so if I'm out in the sun walking the boardwalk or whatever, I should wear a hat over the wig.  The rays can damage the synthetic hair.  Penny

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 01:27PM redwolf8812 wrote: I'm on daily celexa and ativan "as needed".  My most recent breakdown was Saturday.  My family and I were on our drive home from Florida.  I'm tired of feeling repulsive.  No hair, extra weight, and skin issues.  My husband constantly tells me that he still sees the young woman he married 18 years ago when he looks at me.  He does all the cooking, shopping, and running kids around.  I don't feel I deserve him.  My kids miss out on things.  If I'm being punished for past wrongs, why bring my family down with me?  I told him I just feel like I should stop fighting so he can find a real woman and the kids can get on with their lives. He again said all the right things and I felt better.  Thank God these meltdowns don't happen too often.

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2015 03:34AM redwolf8812 wrote: Hi, Sham. I don't know if this will help your mom but it's worth a try. Vitamin B-6 (100 mg) - 1 pill/day. I take it and it eases the symptoms but sometimes I need to take painkillers to really help. I nap a lot, get off my feet, etc. Chemo side effects are cumulative so it doesn't always matter when she gets her dose. Some side effects we just have to live with and try things that make us as comfortable as possible. There's also a scrip that she can ask her oncologist for. I think it's called neurontin. Praying your mom finds relief. - Penny

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2014 10:31PM redwolf8812 wrote: I'm on federal disability.  I also applied for, and receive, my pension from my job.  I'm younger than the mandatory collection age for the pension but it was approved based on my disability.  Between the two, my income is comparable to what I was making before I quit working.  But there was a waiting period, during which I received donated sick pay from my co-workers (I am blessed!).  Without that, times would've been really tough, but my husband was adamant that we would do whatever we had to.  I could've worked some of the time (and wanted to), but not having to worry about it sure did take a lot of stress off me.  It'll be a year next month since I quit. Wish I could answer your insurance questions, but we're also blessed with a good job for my husband, and I use his insurance. Keep us posted on your decision! - Penny

Posts.Content: Apr 9, 2012 01:34PM redwolf8812 wrote: I'm Roman Catholic and attend mass with my family every Sunday and on holy days of obligation.  I pray the rosary every day and go to adoration once/week.  My faith definitely got stronger with my diagnosis.  I really don't know why, though.  I just started feeling everyone's love and prayers and realized that I don't deserve any of the blessings Jesus has given me.  I know that when we get to Heaven we will finally know why bad things happen, for God's purposes, whatever they may be. I remind myself and my children that there are families going through much worse, and that they should not, under any circumstances, use this stupid cancer as an excuse to turn from God or to live their lives as derelicts.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2013 09:09PM redwolf8812 wrote: I had mammograms every year.  When I felt a lump, it was a week before I was due for my yearly mammogram.  The mammogram and ultrasound showed a gigantic tumor.  The breast surgeon said he felt it had been probably growing for at least 2 years.  Then I found out that tumors don't show in mammograms of women with dense breasts.  I had dense breasts.  WHY didn't anyone warn me?  Why wasn't I told to get a breast MRI instead of a mammogram?  I wasted my time with those mammograms and here I am, going to die an early death because no one could bother to give correct information.  Instead, let's just tell women to get mammograms every year and they'll be fine!  YEAH RIGHT. I CANNOT STAND KOMEN AND EVERY TIME I SEE A PINK RIBBON I WANT TO THROW UP. Penny
Posts.Title: oh this makes me so mad! 4myangels justjudie

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2015 05:37AM redwolf8812 wrote: Allyme - I know how you feel, also. Sometimes I cry and wonder, "why me?" and than I think, "why NOT me?" God doesn't make bad things happen to us - that all started with Adam & Eve, blah, blah, blah, we all know the story of free will. But I truly believe he takes bad situations and makes good come from it. My diagnosis caused me and my family and several friends to become closer to God; my husband and I have reconciled and love each other more than ever; etc. But every time I get MRI results I become more despondent. I don't think I'll ever hear NED (been fighting for almost 5 years), but I love Him so much and am so grateful to still be here and get to see milestones I didn't think I'd be around for. I also think, "we all have to die SOME time. I just happen to know that I'll be going a little sooner than I thought and I also know what will likely kill me". So I continue to say my daily prayers for me, my family, friends, medical team, and all cancer patients. I offer up my sufferings and pray it's working. We can only do the best we can at this point and make sure that we love big. Penny

Posts.Content: May 27, 2013 09:28AM redwolf8812 wrote: I'm also Er-/PR-/HER2+ with liver mets.  Don't lose hope.  You have many chemos and cocktails to try.  There is also targeted therapies, such as ablation, sir-spheres, SBRT, & chemoembolization.  I've gone through about 7 chemos and my oncologist is still pretty upbeat, despite my depression about the whole thing.  Herceptin doesn't seem to work for me either, and tykerb almost killed me, I was so allergic to it.  Insurance denied perjeta for me.  I just started T-DM1.  There are many women on www.her2support.org who have to go through many different combinations (always with herceptin and/or tykerb) before they find one that works.  You may want to check it out.  And, as cheery said, a biopsy of those liver mets is important to make sure it's still the same receptors. Prayers for all, Penny
